Hi Ken,

Although I can't say much on this but with the amount of knowledge he
(Xin Yao) has, Im sure he knows about NEAT. Neuroevolution being one
of Xin's favourite topics, he surely couldn't have missed it. At the
moment he is out for yet another conference (poor me!) otherwise I
could have had a chat with him about NEAT...I will when he is back.

Arjun



--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@c...> wrote:
> Hey Arjun and Kennon, just out of curiosity do either of you know,
> does Xin Yao know about NEAT?  I wonder what his thoughts would be.
> 
> ken
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Arjun Chandra" <arjunchandra2k3@y...>
> wrote:
> > (apologies, off-topic again)
> > 
> > That coursemate would be *ME*. Xin Yao is a great speaker and a 
> > highly motivating and encouraging supervisor as well and yes it
> sure 
> > is very hard to catch him. I am currently writing a paper with
him 
> > which of course deals with the group's favourite topic - 
> > neuroevolution, but from an ensemble learning perspective. 
> > 
> > I'll second to Kennon's view on this MSc programme. It indeed is 
> > intellectually stimulating.
> > 
> > cheers,
> > Arjun
> > 
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Kennon Ballou <msc92klb@c...> wrote:
> > > (a bit off-topic, my apologies)
> > > 
> > > xin yao is one of my lecturers here at birmingham :)
> > > 
> > > he is a very good speaker. i say that he's my lecturer; 
> > unfortunately 
> > > after the first two weeks he got someone else to cover the rest
> of 
> > the 
> > > lectures this term (Yong Liu, who despite being the co-creator
of 
> > > negative correlation learning, and quite a brilliant and nice
> guy, 
> > is 
> > > not a particularly good lecturer.)
> > > 
> > > i see this is why my coursemate (whose project Xin is
> supervising) 
> > can 
> > > never see him, since he's off wasting time at these stupid 
> > conferences 
> > > in america :)
> > > 
> > > by the way, if any of you are looking for an MSc programme,
mine 
> > so far 
> > > has been excellent - it has been a very good overview of 
> > evolutionary 
> > > computation, neural computation, nature inspired optimisation, 
> > etc. a 
> > > large portion of the faculty here is involved in naturally 
> > inspired 
> > > methods including neuroevolution, and it has been very 
> > intellectually 
> > > stimulating.
> > > 
> > > -KB-
> > > 
> > > Kenneth Stanley wrote:
> > > > Yeah the guy giving the NN tutorial is Xin Yao, who is famous 
> > for his
> > > > 1999 pre-NEAT paper on neuroevolution, "Evolving Neural 
> > Networks,"
> > > > which was and probably still is the most comprehensive review
> of 
> > the
> > > > field.  But unfortunately at least in past years it looks
like 
> > his
> > > > tutorial is mostly from that era, so it's missing a lot of
the 
> > recent
> > > > developments in the field like NEAT.  (Of course this year
> could 
> > be
> > > > different.)  Still, I recommend checking it out since he's a
> well
> > > > known researcher and his perspective may be useful.
> > >
